framework_intro.para: Below is a suggested framework to help you structure this type of report. There are spaces for you to add your notes and the content of your report.
Remember that you can look the word up in the Oxford Advanced Learner's Dictionary.

commentary.para: Graphs can be used to compare many different things. Line graphs are usually used to show developments over a period of time.
Below is the framework that was used to create this report.
In order to plan the report, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.
Start with a general comment on the trends shown in the graph, plus the main trend.
Provide supporting detail on the main trend.
Compare these trends with other expenditure.
Summarize the main contrast in the trends.
The writer uses key words and phrases for reporting on data.

checklist.point: Examine the data you are reporting on and make notes.
Ask yourself questions about what the graph shows.
Organize the information so that you highlight the main trends or features.
Use language that is plain and simple, but academic in style.
Use language to describe general trends.
Use language to describe developments over time.
Have I introduced the subject of the data?
Have I picked out the main trends in the information?
Have I made some interesting comparisons between trends or figures?
Have I reported the data accurately?
Does the conclusion summarize the data?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?

content.para: Summarize the information in the graph by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.

paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc: Describe the subject of the data

notes.para: Graph: proportion of total expenditure that UK households spent over 50 years on: housing; fuel, light and power; food; clothing and footwear; transport and vehicles.

content.para: The graph shows what proportion of their total expenditure households in the UK spent, over a fifty year period, in five different categories: housing; fuel, light and power; food; clothing and footwear; and transport and vehicles.

paragraph.name: Trends
paragraph.desc: Make a general comment on the trends shown in the data and explain the main trend with supporting detail.

notes.para: Expenditure changed in all categories. Food: biggest change, from 30% of total to 15%.

content.para: Between 1957 and 2007 expenditure in all five categories changed to some extent, but the most marked change was in the food category. At the beginning of the period the proportion of expenditure on food was more than three times as high as that in all the other categories, representing more than thirty per cent of total household expenditure. However, by 2007 this figure had more than halved to around fifteen per cent, and was slightly less than expenditure on both housing and transport.

paragraph.name: Compare trends
paragraph.desc: Explain other similar trends and give details and compare these trends with others.
paragraph.tip: TIP The number of paragraphs you use will depend on the amount of data you are writing about.

notes.para: Clothing and footwear (10% - 5%) + fuel, light and power (6% - 3%) also fell. Less spent on these than other categories.

content.para: The two other areas where proportions of expenditure fell over the period are clothing and footwear, and fuel, light and power. However, the changes here were much less dramatic. Expenditure on the former dropped steadily from ten per cent to five per cent, and on the latter from six per cent to three per cent. For most of the fifty-year period, these categories used up a significantly smaller proportion of the household budget than the others.

paragraph.name: Contrast trends
paragraph.desc: Give more detail on trends which show a different pattern and summarize the main contrast in the trends.

notes.para: At the end of the period - most was spent on housing, least on fuel, light and power.

content.para: In two categories, transport and housing, the proportions of expenditure almost doubled, rising from eight and nine per cent to sixteen and nineteen per cent respectively. Thus, by the end of the period, the highest proportion of household expenditure went on housing, and the lowest on fuel, light and power.

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.desc: Summarize the report with a general conclusion.

notes.para: Over 50 years, patterns of spending changed, proportion spent on food changing most.

content.para: In conclusion, the graph shows that the patterns of spending in UK households changed to some extent over the period 1957 to 2007, the part of the budget spent on food showing the most marked change.
